metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case involves a challenge to the constitutionality of a Washington state requirement that voter...

target:
This case involves a challenge to the constitutionality of a Washington state requirement that voters live at their address for at least 30 days before casting their ballot (the "durational residency requirement" or "DRR"). Washington state authorities reached an agreement to remove the durational residency requirement.

On the November 7, 2023 complaint (as amended on November 20, 2023), the Washington State Alliance for Retired Americans sued (i) Steve Hobbs in his official capacity as Washington Secretary of State, (ii) Mary Hall in her official capacity as Thurston County Auditor, and (iii) Julie Wise in her official capacity as King County Elections Director, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, alleging that the Washington State DRR violates the Voting Rights Act and the U.S. Constitution's First and Fourteenth Amendments because the DRR prohibits any voter who has moved into or within the state within 30 days of an election from registering and voting at their address.

On March 15, 2024, the parties entered into a Consent Judgment and Decree, pursuant to which the Defendants agreed with the Alliance’s claims that the state’s 30-day pre-election durational residency requirement imposed on registrants and voters violates Section 202(c) of the Voting Rights Act Amendments of 1970 (“VRA”), 52 U.S.C. § 10502(c), and the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, U.S. Const. amends. I, XIV.

On same date, the Court granted the join, unopposed motion to enter the proposed consent decree, which served as final judgment.

On September 16, 2024, Franklin County Auditor Matt Beaton and Washington State Republican Party chairman Jim Walsh moved to intervene as defendants in the case. In their motion, Beaton and Walsh argued primarily that they should be allowed to intervene based on their allegations that the underlying litigation was collusive and that Defendants failed to advance potentially meritorious arguments challenging Plaintiff’s Article III standing.

On October 11, 2024, the Court denied the motion to intervene as defendants in the case from Beaton and Walsh as they have not met their burden to show that they timely moved to intervene.
target_paragraph: This case involves a challenge to the constitutionality of a Washington state requirement that voters live at their address for at least 30 days before casting their ballot (the "durational residency requirement" or "DRR"). Washington state authorities reached an agreement to remove the durational residency requirement.

annotation.explanation: Violation of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution (U.S. Const. amend. XIV)
Removal of the 30-day durational residency requirement.

The case involves a constitutional and VRA challenge to Washington’s 30-day durational residency requirement that prevents voters who moved into or within the state within 30 days of an election from registering and voting at their new address, supported by documentary records including a consent judgment in which defendants agreed the DRR violates Section 202(c) of the VRA and the First and Fourteenth Amendments and a court order entering the decree as final judgment, with background information such as the state authorities’ agreement to remove the requirement.
Durational residency requirement: voters must live at their address for at least 30 days before voting; it prevents voters who moved within 30 days from registering and voting at their new address.
Background: State authorities agreed to remove the durational residency requirement.
Defendants agreed to remove the 30-day durational residency requirement for voting.
Defendants agreed, via a March 15, 2024 Consent Judgment and Decree, to remove the 30-day durational residency requirement for voting.

Violation of the Voting Rights Act, specifically Section 202(c) of the Voting Rights Act Amendments of 1970, 52 U.S.C. § 10502(c)

annotation.explanation: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as Washington State Alliance for Retired Americans
Plaintiff: Washington State Alliance for Retired Americans
Defendant: Steve Hobbs, in his official capacity as Washington Secretary of State
Defendant: Mary Hall, in her official capacity as Thurston County Auditor
Defendant: Julie Wise, in her official capacity as King County Elections Director

Parties, forum, and filing: On November 7, 2023 (amended November 20, 2023), the Washington State Alliance for Retired Americans sued the Washington Secretary of State, Thurston County Auditor, and King County Elections Director in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.
Claims: The DRR allegedly violates the Voting Rights Act and the First and Fourteenth Amendments because it bars recent movers (within 30 days) from registering and voting at their address.
Complaint filed on November 7, 2023, by the Washington State Alliance for Retired Americans.
Amended complaint filed on November 20, 2023.
